bestBHT.bht: In the face of a man possessed by an unclean spirit, Jesus exercised his authority by rebuking the spirit and commanding it to come out without causing bodily harm. Notably, Luke, a physician, carefully observed this detail and emphasized that Jesus did not injure the man in any way while freeing him from the grip of the spirit. This demonstrates Jesus' compassion and skill in dealing with those tormented by evil spirits, showcasing his ability to confront darkness while preserving physical well-being.

Henry Alford: 35.] hurt him not is here only. St. Mark’s expression, rendered “torn,” may mean ‘having convulsed him’—and our text, ‘without doing him bodily injury.’
Marvin Vincent: Hold thy peace [φιμωθητι] . Lit., be muzzled or gagged."
Had thrown [ριψαν] . Used in connection with disease by Luke only, and only here. In medical language, of convulsions, fits, etc."
Hurt him not [μηδεν βλαψαν αυτον] . Lit., in no possible way. Mark omits this detail, which a physician would be careful to note.
Archibald T. Robertson: First aorist (effective) participle of ριπτω, an old verb with violent meaning, to fling, throw, hurl off or down.
Luke as a physician carefully notes this important detail not in Mark.
Βλαπτω, to injure, or hurt, occurs in the N.T. only here and in Mark 16:18, though a very common verb in the old Greek.
John Gill: Hold thy peace, or 'be thou muzzled', as the word signifies."
He came out of him, and hurt him not; though he sadly convulsed him, and put him to great pain, yet he did not wound him in any part of his body, or take away the use of any of his limbs."
All which was desired and intended by him, but was hindered by Christ.

bhtAttempts.bht: When faced with a man possessed by an unclean spirit, Jesus displayed his power and authority by rebuking the spirit and commanding it to come out of the man. The man convulsed and experienced great pain, but Jesus did not physically harm him. Instead, Jesus demonstrated his control over the situation without causing any bodily injury. This detail, carefully noted by Luke as a physician, highlights the compassion and skill of Jesus in dealing with those who are tormented by evil spirits.

When faced with a possessed man, Jesus demonstrated his power and authority by rebuking the unclean spirit and commanding it to come out without inflicting bodily harm. Luke, a physician, carefully noted this important detail, highlighting Jesus' compassion and skill in dealing with those tormented by evil spirits. Despite convulsions and great pain, Jesus showed control over the situation, ensuring that the man's physical well-being was preserved. This momentous event showcases Jesus' ability to confront spiritual darkness while treating those in need with gentleness and care.

In the presence of a man possessed by an unclean spirit, Jesus exercised his authority by rebuking the spirit and commanding it to come out without causing any bodily harm. Luke, a physician, carefully noted this crucial detail, emphasizing that Jesus did not injure the man in any way while freeing him from the grip of the spirit. Jesus demonstrated both his power over the forces of darkness and his compassion for those who suffered, skillfully navigating the delicate balance between confronting evil and preserving physical well-being.

When confronted with a man possessed by an unclean spirit, Jesus, displaying his power and authority, rebuked the spirit without causing any bodily harm. This notable detail, carefully observed by Luke as a physician, highlights the compassion and skill of Jesus in dealing with those tormented by evil spirits. Despite the convulsions and great pain experienced by the man, Jesus maintained control over the situation, ensuring the preservation of his physical well-being. This event serves as a testament to Jesus' ability to confront spiritual darkness while demonstrating care and gentleness towards those in need.

In the face of a man possessed by an unclean spirit, Jesus exercised his authority by rebuking the spirit and commanding it to come out without causing bodily harm. Notably, Luke, a physician, carefully observed this detail and emphasized that Jesus did not injure the man in any way while freeing him from the grip of the spirit. This demonstrates Jesus' compassion and skill in dealing with those tormented by evil spirits, showcasing his ability to confront darkness while preserving physical well-being.
